Sergeant Lavi Gehasi was a young man of boundless energy and optimism, known for his radiant spirit and unwavering dedication to helping others. Born and raised in Hashmonaim, he was the beloved son of Orit and Yaakov Gehasi and the cherished brother of Noam, Yigal, and Yedidia. At just 19 years old, he fell in battle in the northern Gaza Strip on December 20, 2023, while serving as a combat soldier in Battalion 931 of the Nahal Brigade during the Iron Swords War. Lavi’s life and sacrifice embodied his deep commitment to his family, his community, and his country.

Family Life

Lavi’s family remembers him as a beacon of warmth and kindness, whose presence was a constant source of joy and support. His mother, Orit, described Lavi as someone who fought courageously, eager to face challenges head-on. “Lavi was a lion,” she said, referencing his name, which means lion in Hebrew. “He fought with determination in this war, always with a compassionate heart and an enveloping hug.” His family takes solace in knowing that his sacrifice was not in vain and believes that his spirit will continue to inspire unity and love among the people of Israel.

Lavi’s brother, Yigal, shared a touching letter that Lavi had written to him from Gaza, in which Lavi expressed both the hardships he faced and his faith in divine love: “I am writing to you after ten days in Gaza, with some unpleasant incidents that happened in the unit, but also miracles. I understood that God loves His children like a mother loves us. Never forget that, even in less pleasant moments.” This letter is a testament to Lavi’s deep faith and positive outlook, even in the face of adversity.

Military Service and Heroic Sacrifice

Sergeant Lavi Gehasi’s journey in the Nahal Brigade was marked by dedication and a desire to serve. After recently completing a rigorous course in the brigade, he immediately expressed his eagerness to join the fight in Gaza, driven by his sense of duty to protect his nation. During his service, Lavi demonstrated exceptional courage and determination, traits that earned him the respect and admiration of his comrades.

He found immense fulfillment in contributing to his country, particularly after engaging in intense battles in Jabalia. His brother Noam recalled the spark in Lavi’s eyes, noting the immense satisfaction he felt from his role as a protector of Israel. For Lavi, military service was more than a duty—it was a mission he embraced wholeheartedly, seeing it as a vital contribution to the safety and security of his people.

Lavi’s ultimate sacrifice on the battlefield in northern Gaza left a lasting impact on those who knew him. His funeral, attended by his fellow soldiers and loved ones, was a solemn yet proud moment, as the Israeli flag was draped over his casket, symbolizing the heroism with which he lived and fought.

Personal Achievements and Volunteering Spirit

Beyond his military achievements, Lavi Gehasi was equally remarkable for his dedication to helping those in need. He volunteered extensively with children with special needs, most notably mentoring a young boy named Ido for three years. Lavi’s commitment to Ido was profound, spending weekends with him and offering his unwavering support, despite the boy’s inability to fully recognize or remember his name. This act of selfless love exemplified Lavi’s character—always giving without expecting anything in return.

Avri Gilead, a journalist who met Lavi during Simchat Torah a year before the war, described him as a young man with a heart full of kindness, likening his generosity to the sweetness of pomegranate honey. Gilead was moved by Lavi’s dedication to mentoring Ido, highlighting it as a true expression of joy and faith. Lavi’s actions were not just about fulfilling a duty; they were a manifestation of his belief in the value of every individual and his desire to make a meaningful difference in their lives.

Continuing His Legacy

After Lavi’s tragic death, his younger brother Yedidia stepped up to continue Lavi’s legacy of compassion by taking over his mentorship of Ido. Inspired by Lavi’s spirit of giving, Yedidia committed himself to fill the void that Lavi’s passing had left in Ido’s life. He now accompanies Ido to his activities, spends time with him, and ensures that the bond Lavi had built with him remains strong. Yedidia’s actions are a powerful tribute to Lavi’s life and values, demonstrating that his legacy of love and dedication lives on through his family.

Their mother, Orit, expressed immense pride in Yedidia for continuing Lavi’s path of volunteerism, a journey that Lavi had dedicated his life to. The Gehasi family has also become involved in the “Fill the Void” initiative, which encourages young people to honor fallen soldiers by engaging in acts of service and supporting the bereaved families. Through this initiative, Lavi’s spirit of selflessness and commitment to others continues to inspire new generations to make a difference.

A Hero Remembered

Lavi Gehasi’s life was a testament to the power of compassion, dedication, and courage. He was more than just a soldier; he was a young man whose kindness touched everyone he met, whose faith guided him in times of darkness, and whose bravery led him to make the ultimate sacrifice for his country. As his friend said, Lavi loved the people of Israel and was deeply connected to his faith and his nation. Even in the face of danger, he remained resolute in his mission to defend his homeland.

Lavi’s name is now etched in the annals of Israel’s history as a symbol of heroism and unwavering devotion to the values he held dear. His story is a reminder that the legacy of a hero is not just in how they lived but also in the lives they touched and the inspiration they leave behind. Lavi Gehasi will forever be remembered as a lion-hearted warrior, a compassionate soul, and a true hero of Israel.
